Title:
Recurrent double allopolyploidy in the African S. planifolium
(Sphagnaceae)
Abstract:
Microsatellites, sequences, and flow cytometry were used
to determine if two sympatric African peat mosses (Sphagnum planifolium
and S. slooveri) had a history of intersubgeneric hybridization and to
assess their phylogenetic relationship. Both species had previously not
been considered to be hybrids. Sphagnum slooveri was found to be an
inter-subgeneric allodiploid allopolyploid, with the maternal parent
being S. recurvum s.s. (or a closely related species) of subg. Cuspidata
and the paternal parent being an unidentified species from the S.
africanum complex of subg. Subsecunda. Sphagnum planifolium was found to
be a cryptic species complex of inter-subgeneric allotriploid
allopolyploids, with recurrent allopolyploidy resulting in at least two
evolutionarily distinct lineages. The maternal parent of both lineages
was S. slooveri. The paternal parent of one lineage (S. planifolium I)
was an unidentified haploid associated with the S. capense complex of
subgenus Subsecunda. The paternal parent of the second lineage (S.
planifolium II) was S. cuspidatum (or a closely related species) of
subg. Cuspidata. As two rounds of allopolyploidy were associated with
their evolution, both lineages of S. planifolium s.l. are double
allopolyploids. Four double allopolyploid species are now documented in
bryophytes, all in Sphagnum. As the allodiploid parent for each of the
four double allopolyploids had a history of intersubgeneric
hybridization, high genetic divergence between subgenomes may facilitate
the evolution of double allopolyploidy in Sphagnum. Although its
provenance is equivocal, a highly disjunct population of S. recurvum is
reported for Amsterdam Island. Genetic analyses reveal that S.
pulchricoma, S. recurvum, and S. sanctojosephense form a complex of
non-hybrid and intra-subgeneric hybrid plants in the neotropics, with
the hybrids having a history of hybridization between S. cuspidatum and
S. recurvum.
